title: 103_s1429
content: The Act titled "Women and AIDS Research Initiative Amendments of 1993" establishes a program for research on women and Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) under the Public Health Service Act. The Act establishes a program for biomedical and behavioral research on HIV cases in women, including prevention research. Research includes transmission of HIV to women, relationship with other sexually transmitted diseases, and clinical trials on preventing HIV through treating STDs in women. The Act establishes a program for research on HIV cases in women, including prevention research on transmission and relationship with other sexually transmitted diseases. Research includes prevention measures such as rapid diagnostic tests, single-dose therapy, and prevention methods for women. The Act includes research on HIV cases in women, focusing on prevention measures like rapid diagnostic tests, single-dose therapy, prevention methods for women, symptoms progression, treatment, and behavioral research for prevention. The Act also includes clinical trials for women infected with HIV, ensuring gynecological evaluations and appropriate follow-up. The Act mandates gynecological evaluations for women participating in HIV clinical trials to analyze the relationship between gynecological conditions and HIV infection. Additionally, it requires trials to assess the effectiveness of standard treatments for gynecological conditions arising from HIV infection. The Act mandates gynecological evaluations for women in HIV clinical trials to assess treatment effectiveness for conditions related to HIV infection. Support services like transportation and child care are provided for women participating in these trials. The Secretary shall provide women participating in clinical trials with transportation, child care, and support services, including medical and mental health services. Services will address domestic violence and the particular needs of women in trials, with training for trial conductors. The Secretary conducts research on barrier methods for preventing sexually transmitted diseases, prioritizing identified research needs and opportunities. The Secretary prioritizes research needs and opportunities identified at a National Institutes of Health meeting on topical microbicides, focusing on early infectious processes, formulation of new preparations, clinical testing, and studies on acceptability and compliance. Additionally, the Secretary conducts epidemiological research. The Secretary conducts or supports epidemiological research to determine risk factors for HIV infection in women, including the use of contraceptive methods, tampons, the relationship with other STDs, and substance abuse. The Secretary is conducting a study on the progression of HIV infection in women, known as the Women's Interagency HIV Study. The study aims to include at least 5,000 women with HIV infection and investigate the relationship between infection and substance abuse, including cocaine use, and sexual activity. The Women's Interagency HIV Study includes at least 5,000 women with HIV infection and will be conducted at multiple sites over a minimum of 8 years. The study will focus on the relationship between CD4 cells and the development of serious illnesses in women with HIV, addressing gynecological and other women-specific conditions. The term 'human immunodeficiency virus' is defined as the etiologic agent for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Authorization of appropriations for clinical trials is also mentioned. Authorizations of Appropriations for clinical trials include $20,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 for subsection (c)(1), $10,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 for subsection (c)(2), and $10,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 for subsection (c)(3), with additional funding for fiscal years 1995 through 1996. For fiscal year 1994, $10,000,000 is authorized for subsection (c)(3), and for fiscal years 1995 through 1996, necessary sums are authorized. For subsection (c)(4), $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1994, and necessary sums for 1995 and 1996. Prevention programs are allocated $30,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 for subsection (d)(1), with necessary sums for 1995 through 1996. For fiscal year 1994, $30,000,000 is allocated for prevention programs under subsection (d)(1), $10,000,000 for subsection (d)(2), and $15,000,000 for an interagency study under subsection (e). Necessary sums are authorized for fiscal years 1995 through 1996 for each of these purposes.
